title: Rotational dynamics - torque from forces on disk

content.question: The disk shown in the top-view figures is on a horizontal surface and is free to move with negligible friction. In both figures, two forces of magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> are exerted on the disk at the locations and in the directions shown. Which of the following correctly indicates whether the net torque exerted on the disk about its center of mass is greater in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> or Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, because both forces exert a clockwise torque.
Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, because the net force on the disk is greater.
Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, because the line of action of one of the forces passes through the center of mass.

Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, because the forces in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> cancel each other out.

content.answer: Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, because both forces exert a clockwise torque.
